Response: NA; we didn't have any changes

WE have dedicated teams in our service lines that are tackling issues around patient identification and notification and post-acute tracking, decision making and patient support.  we examine reasons for readmission.

The notification to beneficiaries is problematic.  The DRGs that drive attribution may not be known before or during a hospitalization.  The procedure delivered in a cath lab and its relationship to the OP PCI bundle may not be known until it is done in the cath lab.  Pretending that the patient has a choice of provider (in or out of bundles) with the exception of planned procedures (joint replacement) is a charade and even when presented ahead of time patients ask if they can be excluded but keep their surgeon.  This whole issue needs to be rethought  immediately and dropped until a better process is identified.
NA; we are a Non-Convener Participant

The legalities of having to have in place with individual providers within the single provider practice that is a sharing partner is cumbersome to the point that we are simply sharing with the practice and not including specific providers.
NA; we don't have relationship with a BPCI Advanced Entity
NA; we don't participate in ICS Sharing
We use a Milliman claims tool that allows us to track expenditures per epsiode against against a risk adjusted target
NA; we don't use Fraud and Abuse Waivers

Benes do not understand the document as written, do not understand what options they do or don't have, and ask to retain their provider/health system but are suspicious of the government's involvement.

BPCI-A has allowed our system to better engage specialists in accountable/value-based care activities, a positive.The negative is that this is viewed as just another way to harass hard working care providers

We can watch individual patient patterns of care specifically around readmissions and complications after a procedure or hospitalization.  Many of our programs are linked to Center of Excellence programs that require quality assurance monitoring.

Every CMS system has different requiremetns and lay-outs and it makes it difficult to identify issues that need attention.  For example, this survey was buried 3 levels into the interface and when logging in there was no notification of the requirement.

Trying to apply all of the exclusions to BPCI_A inclusion for benes has resulkted in us notifying essentially all Medicare FFS benes as potential included patients.  If the notification process were dropped, or was simply displaying some posters, everyone would be happier with the process.
